critique: This executive order, issued during World War II, consolidates agencies related to foreign economic affairs under the Office of Economic Warfare. It centralizes control over economic activities related to the war effort, transferring functions and resources from various entities to a single office headed by a presidential appointee. The order explicitly references the First War Powers Act, indicating a reliance on wartime emergency powers. Given the context of WWII, several aspects of this order lean towards central control and prioritizing national interests. Ideologically, it reflects a pragmatic approach to wartime governance rather than a specific left-right leaning. Immigration is not directly addressed. Executive power is expanded to effectively manage the war. Federalism is expanded as well. National security is prioritized over civil liberties. Economic regulation is expanded. Social inclusion is not directly addressed.
